reviewText:
So first things first you will need 64bit Java to run this game well and without crashes.
Gridworld is a very interesting simulator of evolution. When I first began playing I knew little about the controls for changing terrain or food and was more or less at the mercy of natural selection with what came of my world.

My First 3 Hours
For the first hour of eager scrutiny of my first world I saw nothing but failures of creatures. Organisms that could reproduce but lacked a mouth. Creatures that emitted poison but lacked the ability to survive contact with that poison. Animals that could eat but not move, etc, etc. Most of them died off quite rapidly. I saw the slightest glimmer of hope when I noticed a creature moving, eating, and reproducing but when it would reproduce, the parent would die and the offspring without much energy to begin with, would die very soon after if not directly next to some food. By and large these creatures all seemed doomed and world would become a lifeless hulk of uneaten food.

I walked away from the computer and left my game on. watched a television show, came back and saw not much had changed. Having left the TV on I left the room again to turn it off, sat down at my computer and stared at the screen.

That's when I noticed a small group of creatures moving and eating food in the top right of the world.

I immediately zoomed in to see these organisms:
1. Moving
2. Eating
3. Reproducing
4. Conserving enough energy to reproduce while keeping the parent alive.

I WAS ECSTATIC. I sat back and watch these creatures, which I have dubbed 'Monchers', take over my world in no time. They spread like wildfire in a world abundant with food and devoid of competition. Now I see my little Monchers evolving with generation after generation, creating better, different, and sometimes flat out worse versions of themselves. Even as I type this the Monchers of my world are much more efficient than the first colony in that top right corner.

With food more scarce and competition increasing between the Moncher species I noticed Monchers with poison emitters to kill of competition, ones with more speed to collect food faster, and ones with less fancy Neurons" as the game calls them
date: which are basically body parts or overall traits of your creature. With less traits though the monchers use less energy
recommended: allowing them to survive longer without a meal and pass on the genetic code.\n\nWith organisms that don't die within minutes
hoursPlayed:
neurons actually become interesting features of your little animals. You wonder where evolution will take them next and what might succeed or fail. What species will die out or dominate.

In Conclusion
This game is an evolutionary petri dish of interesting results. Although actual interaction with the player is limited
voteText: it's more like a simulation than a game. An aquarium or jar of sea monkeys. But this is so much more than a jar of sea monkeys. It's like having a small world of your own. Species to watch and track. You'll see generations live and die. Creatures rise and fall. If you have the imagination to enjoy these small beings
helpfulPercent: and don't mind a back seat view of evolution
votesHelpful:
this is a very interesting game to leave up and watch from time to time.

You will not enjoy this game if you don't like the idea of:
VERY simple pixel graphics.
At times hours of gameplay without change.
Having to make your own stories and use your own imagination for maximum enjoyment. Often times the most world altering moments can happen quickly and without much fanfair. To someone without their mind enveloped in the game world this would appear quite anticlimactic.
This game requires a lot of patience and creativity.

If any of these reasons don't sound appealing to you I would recommend you NOT buy the game. Otherwise I would highly recommend it."

reviewText:
This is not quite a 'game' but a machine learning life simulator with a myriad of tweak-able parameters.

I started with a 400x400.
After a few days of evolution I changed from rock walls into lava.
I halved the weight and energy requirements of neurons.
They evolved to avoid the deadly lava after 2 hours.
I segmented the 'world' into 4 quadrants separated by lava.
This considerably changed the food distribution and replenishment dynamic.
One of the quads went entirely extinct causing the food to pool and resulted in less for the other three quads.
They adapted.
I seeded the extinct, but food rich, quadrant with a select few from each of the other 'living' quads.
All four continued to thrive, one using pheromones, one fighting and stealing energy, one reproducing rapidly and feeding primarily on carcasses and one evolving many eyes to efficiently find food.
I removed the lava dividing the areas to combine all quadrants only leaving the outer lava walls.
So here we are. They are currently mixing and fighting for resources.
I wonder if one species will become dominant or will they all co-exist.

How will you play God? :D

Edit: Before I get into this review I would like to point out what the game does. It plots AIs if you would like to call them that learn completely from scratch in this game to survive in what has been given to them, some don't even know how to move, or what food does or even what the lava does... You could say they learn from trail and error untill they are very smart. It does not follow any guidelines like AIs from CS:GO or any other games, because theses make their own guidelines or rules, which makes them unquie and this whole game" unquie.


If you do not understand what neural networks are or even care about subjects related to Artificial Intelligence and or don't have much interest in that stuff don't bother with this Evolution Simulator even though all of them are like this

reviewText:
Absolutely the best idle game out there:(This is a log of my creatures, it will vary in style as time passes.)

The first 21 hours were spent watching the game fail at randomly generating creatures.

The next 26 hours were spent watching my creatures finally get smart enough to find food on their own.

Next 110 hours had pretty much nothing happen to the creatures, besides getting ever so slightly better at running toward food. ~20500th generation and they do nothing new except produce tons of red pheremones that don't seem to affect anything.

Only 20 hours later, the creatures have decided that red poison is far more preferable than red pheremones and are now filling the screen with poison. The first stages of competition have appeared!

20 minutes later, the red poison creatures killed themselves and now the creatures are evolving to be super fast (and poison free).

I accidentally caused near extinction 30 hours later by making the neural energy cost really high for a moment, then just keeping it raised slightly, and now the creatures are slowing down to save energy (40 jets instead of a high of 45 jets). Creature count is way, way down and they still haven't done any more new interesting things.

Left it on for 2 days while I was away, came back, they were EXTINCT. Also, the game updated, causing old saves to no longer work. I started over.

Creature 2
42 minutes after starting, viable life appeared (yay for random gen.) and they are currently randomly rotating to find food.

23 hours later, they are finding food again.

At 43 hours, they had developed into viruses, inserting their dna into every other creature they touched. To keep things  interesting, I surrounded them with a ring of lava. They suicide into the lava quite often.

The update that forced me to restart really sped up creature replication, they are only 48 hours old and are already at generation 46400.

They are still running into lava, at generation 115,000, 163 hours after starting the simulation (596 hours if this were running at 30 FPS, according to the game).

166 hours in, they now avoid lava!

209 hours in:
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=614764502
also, here are some stats (140,000 generation): http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=614767184

Generation 200,000! This game's natural selection seems to trend toward the most basic of creatures, as it has been 342 hours and my creatures consist of pretty much just jets, mouths, neurons, dna and eyes. Even my attempt to force stingers hasn't led to their development.

Game updated, highest generation was at 246,000. Nothing special happened.

Creature 3
Testing to see what the game will decide is best adapted to a basic lava map.

Even faster this time, in only 10 hours the creatures are moving toward food. They still run into lava, however.

My computer started getting too hot, this review is suspended indefinitely

reviewText:
Really sick if you know what you're looking at. It's neural nets evolving through survival, without fitness functions or goals. Those that eat food and survive can pass their genes on, and that simple rule allows intelligent behavior to appear as a result.

10/10 if you want to see neural nets and a version of the genetic algorithm at work. Seems silly but these same things are used for all sorts of modern problems, from this game to facial recognition and image classification.

If you want to see little evolving AI pixel creatures eat green pixels in a simulation and slowly start to exhibit more intelligent behavior, buy it. If you are interested in machine intelligence, check it out. But it's a simulation, much less a game.

reviewText:
Day 1, evening:
So I start the game with a 250x250 primordial soup and leave it for an hour or two while I go play Bloodborne.  When I get back, all my creatures fall under several groups:
-No ability to move, eat or reproduce, so they spend all their lives spinning over and over.
-The ability to move and rotate, but no way to eat or reproduce, so they wander until they starve
-The ability to eat, but no ability to move or reproduce, so they eat what they spawn on and then die.  Spinning optional.
-The ability to move, eat and rotate... but no way to reproduce.
I decide to leave the game running overnight to see what happens.
Day 2, morning:
Most of the food is gone, but a single species has risen to dominance, at about generation 250.  It's capable of fast movement, rotation, eating and reproduction.  Due to their high speed, I dub them SANIC.  They spend their lives rushing from food source to food source, spitting out a baby every once in a while.  As an experiment, I drop a few meteors here and there, decimating the food supply and the number of creatures.  I leave it running while I go run errands.
Day 2, evening:
I return to a horror show.  Many of the grazers have died, as they can't find food fast enough before they starve.  The surviors are the the 650th generation, and have split into two major subspecies.  One is the descendant of the original grazing SANIC species, having lost much of its speed in order to conserve energy.  The other subspecies is their closely related cousin, who gained the ability to steal energy, and alternate between eating food nodes... and their kin.  They seem to have no ability or desire to diffrentiate between relatives and the grazing species, and devour both with glee.  I've watched several times where instances would consume their children immediately after birth, or children assaulting and eating their parents after birth.  Carcasses litter the world, with a few enterprising creatures having started to show scavenger behavior, eating the dead bodies.  Time will tell how well they thrive.

reviewText:
As many have said, more simulation than game, but you can do fun things.

I have done none of it.  At least not yet.

But this is $.99 (#macklemore).  So I thought I'd give it a go.

Put it on auto switch and follow on my other monitor and played other games, glancing occasionally.  That experience alone has made this worth the dollar to me.

It was entertaining to watch the dominant species at the time, blind, poision emiting, and unable to turn.  It switched to a particular indiviudal, happily making his way along the west edge of the world, travelling along the border and reaping massive food gains from the realitively untouched area of the map.

And then I watched his brethren barrel in from the east, collide with the until recently fortunate friend, poision him, and then push his body into the awaiting embrace of a lava oblivion.

reviewText:
-Created a world
-Got bored with it
-Inported an evolved creature
-The species killed everything including itself (it ate all the food)
-Tried again
-Cool creature evolved naturally
-Began to expand across the world eating everything
-Placed the evolved creature in to compete
-Everything starved

Edit:
-Created a creature that moves around and creates food
-Saved the world from starvation

Edit:
-Turns out that what I thought was food was actually poison
-Didn't matter- the creature kept dying out because it couldn't eat

10/10 would cause (and then try to fix but fail epically) a mass extinction event again

reviewText:
It's fun to watch how your little sandbox evolves, but I hope there will be many more improvements and patches in time...
The UI is a bit crude, full screen is a must and resolution should be higher as well.

That said, for the price of one coffee this is not a bad deal ;)

reviewText: It's really fun to watch. Creatures learn new move sets and abilities over time and you see how (in)effective they are. I also like the minimalistic pixel visualization. But the simulation performance is quite bad. It needs a lot of cpu power and eats more than 500mb of ram.\n\nYou should try it out, if you are a darwin fan and ironically don't care about performance.

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very cool simulation. Reminds me a lot of the mathimatical Game of Life. Simple, yet can resemble our own world with astounding accuracy.

Would love to see a manual for it. The game would be much more engaging if I had a better understanding of each aspect. Are all different colours different types of creatures? Or are the similarly shaded ones related somehow?

Get pretty epic FPS drops on 250x250 grids and high while running it on 64x Java and a ton of RAM, so not sure what is happening there.

All in all however I enjoy my time with this game and will be following it as it is worked on by the dev.

Hatsworth

reviewText: This is an interesting idea but the execution leaves something to be desired. in it's current build the game crashes when it's trying to autosave, making progression impossible. if it could save however, the game is still very rough. terrible framerates despite pixel graphics, deeply flawed and clunky user interface, and all this for bascially a petri dish simulator. reviewText:
The idea is very nice but it's very badly executed.
First of all, you need java 64 bit, because it is written in ♥♥♥♥ing java.
The fact that the choice for programming language is poor is not the worst part, the real problem is the performance. I expected pretty much nothing of java, but this is terrible. This just points out how bad this 'simulator' is programmed. A 12 year old probably did it.
The game also crashes all the time, This of course, is also caused by the lack of brain cells of the developer. Actually the performance of this 'simulator' is so poor that there is a lag in the mouse click of at least one whole second. I am amazed that this incomplete ♥♥♥♥♥♥ performing ♥♥♥♥ is available in the steam store, and that I paid 99c for it. This is the worst 99c I spent in my life. I wish I had given that to the homeless, at least they would be happier with it than I am with this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 'simulator'. T

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This artificial life simulator is amazing.

Watched life evolve from nothing to dominating it's environment.
None of the actions are scripted.  They are all emergent from the neural network each creature has, and evolve over time.
Changing the rules or environment even slightly has major effects on what evolves.

The sim is worth the $1, even with the horrible UI.

Hopefully the DEV continues working on it as it is the best artificial life simulator I've played.

reviewText:
As long as you dont expect a game where you can actually play, you wont be disapointed.
It has more the feel of an experiment simulation. Set the parameter and see where it will go over time.

At the moment, it gets patches often enough to see a progress on the program, wich is a good thing, because stability and speed still need allot of work.

When you can live with a minimal graphic petri dish simulator, this one is great in what it dos. If you look for a game, search on.

Personally, i would like to see the menu improved some .... just bring it into this milenia would be enough .... and of course an improvement in the calculation speed with lots of liveforms in bigger enviorments would be mutch apreciated. (is the program making use of multiple cpu cores at all ??)

reviewText: Gridworld is a pretty fun toy, but it's 90% passive. Apart from setting initial parameters (world type, mutation frequency, etc.), it's mostly about letting your little petri dish world sit and develop. Checking in on it periodically is fun, as you can definitely see progress after several hours, but don't expect a whole lot of detailed interaction. The interface and details do take a little while to get used to, but it's cool to be able to look at fairly detailed information about each organism. I only wish the creator had put in more options to track species" rather than just individuals.\n\nIf you like watching little worlds and systems develop on their own
date: this is the game for you (just don't go in expecting
hoursPlayed: a world as detailed as Rick and Morty's battery). If you're less patient
voteText: or if you need to have more moment to moment control
helpfulPercent: you'd probably be better off buying another game."

reviewText:
i was looking for super cheap games, and for one dollar, i gave this a shot. Here is what i got out of it.
(NOTE: This is NOT a game however, so much as a simulation.)

Overview: GridWorld more or less introduces a concept of order coming from chaos. It starts by creating random bits of AI with random atributes. It has a custom grid that sections off these AI, and generates a field of food, with some basic enviromental conditions.

Gameplay:  While this is more of an educational simulation with the express purpose of demonstrating how evolution from chaos works on a micro scale, there are afew key events to look for.

*The Kickoff-
The goal is to find an AI with atributes that can sustain itself and can have offspring (an organism that can eat, move, and reproduce). This is where most people get irritated because they dont understand how RNG works, and assume the game is broken. But in actuality it can take afew hours for the big kick off" to happen. But once it does
date: the organism will spread like wildfire
recommended: consume the food on the map
hoursPlayed:
and then reach a population equalibrium.

*Observation of mutation and AI-
From here on out
voteText: the dominant AI will have a random chance of mutation with each reproductive cycle. The mutation  will either hurt or help the mutated AI. If it hurts
helpfulPercent: then the AI dies quickly. But if it helps
votesHelpful: the mutated AI will slowly take over the pre-existing non mutated ones because of its better surviability. (my first time around
commentsCount: the AI has the ability to "learn" and can develop some interesting behavioral patterns
column16: in a similar fashon to physical mutation. As an example
column17:
it may learn to avoid the lava boundary.

My opinion:
In my opinion
column18: this is a well made simulation. It perfectly demonstrates order from randomness
column19: and how evolution is a thing. I think the most irritating thing is the GUI
column20: and id like a better explaination of all the functions
column22: along with the AI copy function. Some things id like to see are achievements
column23: as this is a gaming platform
column24: i think some game type things are in order. I think the developer is working as hard as they can on improving these aspects
column25: so i can forgive the games minor flaws. As for the negative reviews ive seen and complaints about how the game "doesnt work"
column26: RNG sometimes isnt in your favor
column27: but thats not the games issue thats just how math works. Anyways
column28: its an all around decent educational simulation
column29: and its kinda an envigorating feeling to have your own little AI world. I would recomend it to anyone with an interest in computer AI
column31: or if you have 99 cents. Thanks for reading!"
